item.title: runconf18
item.description: Worked on this package at @rOpenSci’s 2018 Unconf.

item.title: how I organise my thoughts and time
item.description: my current systems Updated: 2018-08-28 (I wonder if all or some of this should move to the dontpanic readme.) current tweaks switch \(\Phi, \theta, \varphi\) after planning \(\cdot\) pieces piano practice/task switching/pomodoor bullet journal, used to be as portable as possible blog to see if I’ve made any progress on my study problems for today, to track my productivity system, and to learn about my research problems; in short, blog for me, don’t worry about anyone else: but keep it to those three categories; one category per post, etc.

item.title: measures.
item.description: I like Newport’s term deep work. item.title: simulations
item.description: # packages library(tidyverse) library(tictoc) # for timing # set seed for reproducibility set.seed(38) # 'tis a fine age to be single-study simulation The original snippet. # find the original snippet lnormPAR <- function(m, iqr){ mu <- log(m) sigma <- (mu + log(1/2*(iqr + sqrt(iqr^2 + 4*exp(2*mu)))/exp(2*mu)))/qnorm(0.75) list(mu = mu, sigma = sigma) } medianInt <- function(m, iqr, n){ par <- lnormPAR(m, iqr) V <- 1/4/dlnorm(m, par$mu, par$sigma)^2/n ci <- m + c(-1, 1)*qnorm(0.

item.title: statistical rethinking
item.description: Chapter Two Practice Easy Question One Which of the expressions below correspond to the statement: the probability of rain on Monday? P(rain) P(rain|Monday) P(Monday|rain) P(rain,Monday)/P(Monday) Answer Choices (2) and (4). I went looking for solutions and came across this, “the probability of rain on Monday” I think the statement could be interpreted in two different ways. First, the statement might just mean “what is the probability of rain on any given day”.
